author: owocki
content: Hey hey; just saw this.  Gitcoin Passport has no KYC.  (you can play with it at passport.gitcoin.co , it just stores data on ceramic)

author: owocki
content:
IMO Sybil resistence mechanisms reduce to either

1. biometrics
2. KYC 
3. web of trust
4. human presence based

each of these has their own tradeoffs (i agree with that the privacy concerns related to KYC/bio etric are really high, so i somewhat prefer web of trust personally, but thats kind of why passport is pluralistic, deriving its sybil resistence from multiple diff mechanism)

i did a podcast episode with professor bryan ford who has been working on sybil resistence for ~15-20 years, and thats where im sourcing my info from ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PlDOjDu-mpU )

author: sky.cactus
content:
> “stamps” of validation for your identity
GitCoin is functionally a KYC platform.

author: owocki
content: ok, if you are making up definitions, then there is not much for us to talk about.

author: owocki
content: KYC has traditionally had pretty strong nation state identification connotations.  but Passport does not.

author: owocki
content: feel free to play with it or do some research ( https://docs.passport.gitcoin.co/ ) and come back with an informed opinion.

author: sky.cactus
content: ~~KYC in this context just means requiring people to prove who they are.  Asking for an email address, phone number, biometrics, etc. are all forms of identify verification/KYC.~~ Just realized what channel this is in, not an appropriate place to debate GitCoin passport.

author: owocki
content: ̶t̶h̶e̶ ̶p̶r̶o̶b̶l̶e̶m̶ ̶o̶f̶ ̶s̶y̶b̶i̶l resist̶e̶n̶c̶e̶ ̶i̶s̶ ̶n̶o̶t̶ ̶a̶s̶k̶i̶ng peo̶p̶le t̶o ̶p̶r̶o̶v̶e̶ ̶w̶h̶o̶ ̶t̶h̶ey are̶;̶ ̶j̶u̶st ̶t̶hat̶ ̶t̶h̶e̶y̶ ̶a̶r̶e a un̶i̶q̶u̶e̶ ̶h̶uman̶ ̶i̶n̶ a̶ ̶s̶e̶t̶.  okay fine
